section.title: Reading Assignment
section.p: Read Section 11.5 of Applied Discrete Structures. The main idea is that there are certain subsets of groups that qualify as groups in their own right. This is an instance of a more general situation in mathematics where a structure can contain smaller structures. The idea of a subset is the most simple case of this, but we have also seen subgraphs in the study of graphs and trees. Finding all subgroups of a group isn't always easy, but describing and finding the cyclic subgroups of a group is not too difficult. Pay close attention how this is done!

statement.p: Let m \mathbb{Z} = \{m \cdot k \mid k \in \mathbb{Z}\}. Chris says that 7 \mathbb{Z} is a subgroup of 14 \mathbb{Z} because 7 \leq 14. How would you respond to Chris?

section.p: Also, turn in solutions to these exercises:

statement.p: True or false?: The set of all bit strings that begin with a 1 form a submonoid of the monoid of all bit strings with concatination.

solution.p: The statement is false because the empty string doesn't start with a 1 and so the identity element is not in the given set. Explain your answer.

statement.p: True or false?: \{0,25,50,75\} is a subgroup of the additive group \mathbb{Z}_{100}. Explain your answer.
Determine the cyclic subgroup generated by 4 in the group \mathbb{Z}_{11}
Determine the cyclic subgroup generated by 4 in the group \mathbb{U}_{11}

In this exercise, we will consider the orders of the additive groups of integers modulo n for three different values of n, and then speculate on some general results.
Determine the orders of different elements of the group \mathbb{Z}_{5}.
Determine the orders of different elements of the group \mathbb{Z}_{15}.
Determine the orders of different elements of the group \mathbb{Z}_{16}.
Comparing the results you got above, hypothesize on what you would expect for different moduli
Assume that [G;*] is a group and H is a nonempty subset of G. Suppose that we are told that for a, b \in H, we are guaranteed that a^{-1}*b \in H. Prove that H is a subgroup of G.

hint.p: Prove the identity, inverses and closure properties of a subgroup, in that order.

section.title: Handouts
section.p: Here is a reminder of the definition of the associative property.

statement.p: Let * be a binary operation on a set S. We say that * is associative if and only if (a * b) * c = a * (b * c) for all a, b, c \in S.
